questions.question: A 28 year old woman, G2 P1 L1 at 38 weeks gestation is seen in early labor. She has a history of cesarean section done 3 years ago for breech presentation. The obstetrician decides on a cesarean section. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a cesarean section in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Gestational diabetes Explanation: Gestational diabetes that is well-controlled with diet and exercise alone is not an indication for a C-section. Women with GDM can often have a vaginal delivery if there are no other complications. If controlled, there is no significant risk to the mother or fetus. If macrosomia is suspected, then repeat cesarean can be offered. Maternal Indications for Cesarean Delivery Prior Cesarean Delivery: most common Abnormal Placentation (Option A) : Placenta previa and placenta accreta Prior Classical Hysterotomy Prior Uterine Incision Extension Uterine Incision Dehiscence (Option B) Prior Full-Thickness Myomectomy Genital Tract Obstructive Mass Invasive Cervical Cancer Prior Trachelectomy Permanent Cerclage Prior Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery Prior Significant Perineal Trauma Pelvic Deformity HSV or HIV Infection Cardiac or Pulmonary Disease. Cerebral Aneurysm or Arteriovenous Malformation: Increase the risk of a stroke Pathology Requiring Concurrent Intraabdominal Surgery Perimortem Cesarean Delivery Non-reassuring FHR status is also a C/I for TOLAC (Option C) Selection criteria for TOLAC Contraindications for TOLAC One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar Previous classical or inverted T shaped uterine incision Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section Previous more than two lower segment cesarean section Pelvis adequate for fetus Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD Continued labor monitoring possible Presence of other complications in pregnancy: obstetric ( malpresentation , pre-eclampsia , placenta previa) or medical Availability of resources (anesthesia , blood transfusion) for emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of decision Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC Informed consent of the women History of prior uterine rupture Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, page 548 2. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, page 546

questions.question: In a cesarean section, the surgeon requires an instrument to effectively retract the abdominal wall and bladder for better visibility of the lower uterine segment. The instrument is shown below. Name the instrument being used.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Doyen’s retractor Explanation: Doyen’s Retractor: Long metallic instrument with a stout handle at one end. Wide retracting blade at the other end (fan-shaped and curved). Requires an assistant for holding and retraction. Uses: Retracts the abdominal wall and bladder for proper exposure of the lower uterine segment during lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). Introduced after opening the abdomen. Temporarily removed during baby delivery. Reintroduced after delivery and finally removed after toileting the peritoneal cavity. Langenbeck’s retractor (Option A) is a superficial retractor with a long handle and a small solid blade. It can be single- or double-bladed and is used in hernia or superficial surgeries to retract skin, fascia, and aponeurosis. Morris retractor (Option C) is a manual retractor with a flat, curved blade and a beak end. It can be single or double-bladed and is used to retract deep abdominal, loin, subcostal, or other wounds. Deaver’s retractor (Option D) is shaped like a question mark with a broad, curved, long blade and strong handle. It is used to retract the abdominal wall and viscera in major surgeries like vagotomy, cholecystectomy, and gastrectomy.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with a history of two previous cesarean deliveries present in labor at 39 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is not an indication for performing a cesarean hysterectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) History of multiple cesarean deliveries. Explanation: While a history of multiple cesarean sections can increase the risk of complications such as placenta accreta spectrum in subsequent pregnancies, it is not an immediate indication for performing a cesarean hysterectomy on its own. The actual indication would be based on complications that arise during the current delivery, such as severe bleeding, not just the history of prior cesareans. Cesarean Hysterectomy: Definition Cesarean hysterectomy is a surgical procedure performed to remove the uterus during or after a Cesarean delivery Types Total : Entire uterus including cervix removed. Supracervical/Subtotal : Upper uterus removed, cervix intact. Indications Morbidly adherent placenta (Option B) Atonic uterus and uncontrolled postpartum hemorrhage (Option A) Large uterine leiomyoma (parous women) Extensive lacerations with broad ligament hematoma Grossly infected uterus (Option C) Ruptured uterus Postpartum atony Cervical cancer Complications Postoperative hemorrhage Bladder laceration Bowel injury Wound dehiscence Ureteral injury Fistula: Vesicovaginal Ureterovaginal Rectovaginal Thromboembolism Infection Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition Page 562,563 2. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no: 554 3. https://www.glowm.com/section-view/heading/Cesarean%20Hysterectomy/item/134 4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2771379/ 5. https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/obstetr ic-care-consensus/articles/2018/12/placenta-accreta-spectrum#:~:text=Risk%20Factors,-There%20are%20several

questions.question: In a laboring patient with a history of cesarean section, which of the following findings is least likely to indicate uterine rupture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Heavy vaginal bleeding. Explanation: Rupture of Uterus: Is defined as the disruption in the continuity of all three layers of the uterus: endometrium (inner epithelial layer), myometrium (smooth muscle layer) and perimetrium (serosal outer layer). Implies involvement of gravid uterus. Signs and symptoms of Uterine Rupture: Hemodynamic Instability in mother: Hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, nausea, and anxiety. Pain: Sudden ripping abdominal pain. (Option A) Blood in the peritoneum causes referred pain to the chest or shoulder. Bladder Injury: Hematuria (pink, red, or brown urine), potential blood clots may pass through the urethra (can be painful). Fetal Heart Rate: Fetal bradycardia, reduced variability, late decelerations, or absent heart sounds. (Option C) Abdominal Examination: Midline abdominal tenderness. Decreased or absent uterine contractions. (Option D) Vaginal Examination: Minimal vaginal bleeding unless the rupture extends into the vagina or cervix. (Option B) Loss of fetal station occurs if part of the fetus enters the peritoneum. Type of Rupture Incomplete Rupture Complete Rupture Cause Rupture of lower segment scar. Extension of cervical tear into the lower segment with the formation of a broad ligament hematoma. Disruption of upper segment scar. Spontaneous rupture (obstructive or non-obstructive). Peritoneum Remains intact. Disrupted, peritoneal cavity is involved. Fetal/Placental Position Both fetus and placenta remain inside the uterine cavity, or part of the fetus may be between broad ligament layers. Fetus with or without a placenta usually escapes out of the uterus. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559209/ DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page: 400- 403

questions.question: A 30-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with spontaneous onset of labor. On examination, she is found to have a moderate degree of cephalopelvic disproportion. The obstetric team decides to proceed with a trial labor . Which of the following factors is not indicative of a successful outcome of trial labor?

options.C: Android pelvis is better than flat pelvis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Android pelvis is better than flat pelvis. Explanation: Trial Labor: Definition Conduction of spontaneous labor in a minor to moderate degree of cephalopelvic disproportion in an institution under supervision aiming for vaginal delivery. Aims Avoid unnecessary cesarean sections and at delivering a healthy baby. Contraindications Midpelvic and outlet contraction. Complicating factors: Elderly primigravida, Malpresentation, Postmaturity, Pre-eclampsia, Medical disorders like diabetes, heart disease etc. Lack of 24/7 cesarean facilities. Successful Outcome Factors Degree of pelvic contraction. (Option A) Pelvic shape (flat is better than android). (Option C) Favorable vertex presentation. Intact membranes until full dilation. (Option B) Effective uterine contractions. (Option D) Emotional support to the woman. Unfavorable Features Abnormal uterine contractions. Cervical dilation < 1 cm/hour in active phase. Fetal head descent < 1 cm/hour in spite of regular uterine contractions. Arrest of cervical dilation despite oxytocin therapy. Early rupture of membranes. Caput formation and excessive molding. Fetal distress. Duration of Trial Individualized; continue if progress is satisfactory. Terminate if there is arrest of progress of labor for 3-4 hours or if ominous features arise. Termination Methods Any one of the following: Spontaneous delivery with or without episiotomy (30%). Forceps or ventouse (30%). Cesarean section (40%). Successful Trial Vaginal delivery of a healthy baby with mother in good condition. Failure of Trial Cesarean section or delivery of a dead baby. Advantages Avoids unnecessary cesarean section. Reduces preterm induction risks. Ensures better future obstetric outcomes. Disadvantages Tests of disproportion remain unproven if cesarean needed due to fetal distress or uterine dysfunction. Increased perinatal morbidity/ mortality from prolonged/ difficult delivery. Increased maternal morbidity from prolonged labor or operative delivery. Psychological morbidity when trial ends with traumatic vaginal delivery or in cesarean delivery. Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page no: 332,333

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with a previous lower-segment cesarean section is in labor at 39 weeks of gestation and wants to attempt a trial of labor. Which of the following factors is not a benefit of the trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) as compared to elective repeat Cesarean section.?

options.B: Reduced need for future cesarean deliveries.
options.C: Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence. Explanation: Vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) Described as vaginal delivery in a woman who has given birth via cesarean section in a former pregnancy. Patients desiring VBAC delivery undergo a trial of labor (TOL), also called the trial of labor after cesarean section (TOLAC). Selection Criteria of Cases for TOLAC (ACOG) One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar. Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section. Pelvis adequate for the fetus. Continued labor monitoring possible. Availability of resources (anesthesia, blood transfusion and theatre) for an emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of the decision. Informed consent of the woman. Contraindications for TOLAC (indications for Cesarean Delivery) Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision , myomectomy scar Previously >2 LSCS Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD. Presence of other complications in pregnancy: Obstetric (pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placenta previa) or medical. Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC. History of prior uterine rupture Benefits of TOLAC Complications of Unsuccessful TOLAC Decreased maternal morbidity (infection and others). Reduced length of hospital stay. (Option D) Decreased need for blood transfusion. Decreased risk of abnormal placentation (Option A) and need for successive cesarean delivery in next pregnancy. (Option B) Maternal Uterine wound dehiscence. (Option C) Uterine rupture (0.5-1%). Increased blood transfusion. Increased risks of hysterectomy due to uterine rupture. Infections increased maternal morbidity. Perinatal: Low Apgar score, admission to NICU, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), neonatal death, rarely stillbirth. Reference: 1. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Pg.309-311 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK507844/

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman undergoes a cesarean section due to failure to progress in labor. Six months later, she presents with intermittent crampy abdominal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Which of the following is the most likely late complication of her cesarean section?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Adhesion formation Explanation: Early Complication Late Complication Hemorrhage: Uterine atony (Option A) Retained products of conception Incisional site haematoma (bladder flap or subfascial flap hematoma) Uterine dehiscence or rupture (Option B) Iatrogenic vascular complications (uterine arteriovenous malformation, uterine artery pseudoaneurysm) Infective: Puerperal infection (e.g.:endometritis) (Option D) Superficial wound infection Deep pelvic infection (infected haematoma, pelvic abscess) Thromboembolic: Lower limb deep vein thrombosis Acute pulmonary embolism Ovarian vein thrombosis or thrombophlebitis Intestinal obstruction: Due to adhesions or bands or postoperative ileus following peritonitis. Bladder injury Anesthesia complication: Mendelson’s syndrome Hypotension Spinal headache Fetal injuries Cesarean scar defect: Incisional hernia Scar endometriosis Malpositioned intrauterine devices Complications in future pregnancy: Scar ectopic pregnancy Abnormal placentation Intrapartum uterine dehiscence or rupture Cesarean scar retained products of conception Menstrual irregularities Chronic pelvic pain or backache Intestinal obstruction due to adhesions and bands (Option C) Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Pg.552, 553 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9058384/ https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1742271X211038715?icid=int.sj-abstract.citing-articles.7 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6757074/

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman under general anesthesia for an emergency cesarean section suddenly develops acute respiratory distress with cyanosis and decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field. Chest X-ray shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for this condition?

options.C: Maternal anxiety and apprehension during labor.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Increased gastric motility. Explanation: The clinical scenario is consistent with the diagnosis of Mendelson’s syndrome. Increased gastric motility is not a predisposing factor for Mendelson’s syndrome. Mendelson’s Syndrome It is a serious and life-threatening complication caused by aspiration of gastric contents (pH <2.5) under general anesthesia in young and healthy obstetrical patients (especially during cesarean section). Predisposing Factors: Delayed gastric emptying due to (Option D) High serum progesterone levels. (Option A) Decreased motilin. (Option B) Maternal apprehension during labor. (Option C) Complications: Chemical pneumonitis Lung damage Atelectasis Bronchopneumonia Commonly Affected lobe: Right lower lobe (due to aspiration through the right bronchus). Clinical features: Tachycardia Tachypnea Bronchospasm Rhonchi Rales Cyanosis Decreased PaO I Hypotension Diagnosis: Chest X-ray reveals right lower lobe involvement. Management: Immediate suctioning of the oropharynx and nasopharynx to remove inhaled fluid. Bronchoscopy if large particulate matter is present. Continuous positive pressure ventilation (CPAP) to maintain arterial oxygen saturation at 95%. Administration of antibiotics if infection is evident. Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page no: 482 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539764/

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman is scheduled for a cesarean delivery. The obstetrician is considering a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) over a classical cesarean section. Which of the following is an advantage of lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) compared to a classical cesarean section?

options.B: Reduce risk of significant blood loss

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above. Explanation: Aspect Lower Segment Cesarean Section (CSCS) Classical Cesarean Section Techniques Technically slight difficult Technically easy Blood loss is less Blood loss is more The wall is thin, and as such, the apposition is perfect The wall is thick, and the apposition of the margins is imperfect Perfect peritonization is possible Not possible Post- operative Hemorrhage and shock is less (Option B) More Peritonitis is less even in the infected uterus because of perfect peritonization and, if occurs, localized to the pelvis Chance of peritonitis is more in the presence of uterine sepsis Peritoneal adhesions and intestinal obstructions are less More because of imperfect peritonization Convalescence is better Relatively delayed Morbidity and mortality are much lower Morbidity and mortality are high Wound healing The scar is better healed because of: (Option D) The scar is weak because of: Perfect muscle apposition due to thin margins Imperfect muscle apposition because of thick margins Minimal wound hematoma b) More wound hematoma formation The wound remains quiescent during the healing process c) The wound is in a state of tension due to contraction and relaxation of the upper segment. As a result, the knots may slip, or the sutures may become loose Chance of gutter formation is unlikely d) Chance of gutter formation on the inner aspect is more During future pregnancy Scar rupture is less (0.5-1.5%) (Option A) More risk of scar rupture (4-9%) Trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) Possible in next pregnancy (for 1 previous LSCS only) Contraindicated due to risk of uterine rupture Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page no: 310,552 Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no: 559

questions.question: While performing a cesarean section for a woman, the obstetrician decides to give a Kronig incision rather than the usual Kerr incision. Which of the following is an advantage of using Kronig instead of Kerr incision?

options.B: Reduce risk of uterine scar rupture
options.D: Can be given when the lower uterine segment is not well formed.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Can be given when the lower uterine segment is not well formed. Explanation: The only situation where a Kronig incision may be used in CS instead of the usual Kerr incision is if the LUS is not well formed or not enough space to give a Tranverse incision in the LUS. Features Kerr Incisions (Lower segment transverse incision) Kronig Incisions (Lower segment vertical incision) Extension of incision May occur to involve the uterine vessels May occur to involve the upper segment or downward the bladder Bladder dissection Minimal (Option A) More when extends inferiorly Uterine closure Easy Difficult Muscle apposition Good Often imperfect Reperitonization Complete Often imperfect Intraoperative bleeding Less (Option C) More Subsequent adhesions Less More Risk of scar rupture 0.5 - 1% (Option B) 0.8 - 2% (Risk of scar rupture in cases with T or J shaped incision is 2-6%) Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Pg.552

questions.question: Which of the following factors is NOT contributing to the rising rates of cesarean sections? antibiotics. (rotational forceps).

options.A: Increased safety of the operation due to improved anesthesia, availability of blood transfusion, and
options.B: Decline in operative vaginal deliveries (midforceps, vacuum) and manipulative vaginal deliveries
options.C: Decrease in maternal age and associated medical complications.
options.D: Wider use of electronic fetal monitoring and increased diagnosis of fetal distress.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Decrease in maternal age and associated medical complications. Explanation: Cesarean delivery- the birth of the fetus by laparotomy followed by hysterotomy. Not applied to removal of the fetus from the abdominal cavity in the case of uterine rupture or abdominal pregnancy. Primary C-section is the first operation on a patient; subsequent ones are termed repeat C-sections. An increase in maternal age, not a decrease, is associated with higher rates of cesarean sections due to age-related complications. Factors contributing to rising C-section rates Increased safety, better anesthesia, blood transfusion, antibiotics. (Option A) Increased incidence of primary cesarean deliveries. Identification of at-risk fetuses and high-risk pregnancies. Wider use of repeat C-sections. Higher rates of induced labor and failed inductions. Decline in operative vaginal deliveries (forceps, vacuum) and breech deliveries. (Option B) Older maternal age and associated medical conditions. Use of electronic fetal monitoring and increased diagnosis of fetal distress. (Option D) Fear of litigation and cesarean delivery by maternal request. Reference: DC Dutta Obstetrics 9th edition. Pg.545, 546

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient undergoing cesarean delivery is being informed about the implications of different abdominal incisions. Which statement about the side effects of these incisions is NOT accurate?

options.A: Vertical incision increases the risk of infections.
options.B: Transverse incision increases the risk of injury to neurovascular structures.
options.C: Vertical incision increases the risk of incisional hernia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vertical incision increases the risk of infections. Explanation: Complications of Abdominal Incisions: Feature Transverse Incision Vertical Incision Cosmesis Superior, less visible scarring Inferior, scarring present (Option D) Incisional Hernia Rates Lower Higher (Option C) Risk of Fluid Collection Higher; potential for purulent fluid accumulation in the layer created during incision of external and internal aponeurosis. Lower; less risk of fluid accumulation. Infection Risk Higher risk due to layered incision creating spaces for fluid collection. Lower risk. (Option A) Neurovascular Structures May encounter ilio-inguinal and iliohypogastric nerves, superficial and inferior epigastric vessels. (Option B) Less likely to encounter these structures. Bleeding and Hematoma Risk Higher risk due to neurovascular structures. Lower risk Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no: 551,559

questions.question: A 34-year-old patient is scheduled for a cesarean delivery. Which of the following conditions is not an indication of a classical cesarean incision?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Routine elective cesarean Explanation: Upper segment cesarean section (Classical cesarean incision) is not used in routine elective cesarean section as it encompasses the active upper uterine segment and thus is prone to rupture with subsequent pregnancies Indications of Upper segment cesarean section (Classical cesarean incision) Risk of Lower Uterine Segment Complications: Densely adherent bladder from previous surgery. Leiomyoma in the lower uterine segment. Cervical cancer involvement. (Option B) Previous radical trachelectomy for cervical cancer. Placenta-Related Issues: Placenta previa with anterior implantation. Placenta accreta syndrome. (Option A) Maternal Obesity: Massive obesity that prevents safe access to the lower uterine segment. Fetal Indications: Transverse fetal lie with ruptured membrane and impacted shoulder. Transverse lie with the back-down position. (Option C) Very small or breech fetus. Small fetal head entrapped by contracting uterine fundus following membrane rupture. Multiple fetuses that may be malpositioned or preterm. Large fetal malformation or conjoined twins requiring extra space. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Pg. 559

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman at term is undergoing cesarean delivery. Which of the following uterine incisions is preferred?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Low transverse incision Explanation: Low transverse incision is preferred for most cesarean deliveries as it facilitates easier repair, minimizes bleeding, reduces adhesion formation and lowers the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies. Steps in C-section 1. Skin Incision: Pfannenstiel Incision: Incised with a low, transverse, curvilinear incision at the pubic hairline, extending laterally (12-15cm). Joel-cohen incision: Straight, transverse incision 3 cm below the anterior superior iliac spines. 2. Dissection: Subcutaneous Layer: Sharp dissection; use cautery to minimize bleeding. Fascia: Incise midline and extend laterally. Muscle: Rectus abdominis and pyramidalis muscles are separated in the midline to expose transversalis fascia and peritoneum. 3. Access to Abdominal Cavity: Sharp or blunt incision over the peritoneum. 4. Uterine Incision: Low transverse (preferred) or vertical incision. (Option A) 5. Fetal Delivery: Delivered by gently elevating the head with hands. Cord Clamping: Doubly clamp and cut; delayed clamping can be beneficial in some cases. 6. Placenta Delivery: Achieved by spontaneous delivery by gentle traction and fundal massage. Manual removal is an alternative if necessary. 7. Uterine Repair: Uterine incision is closed with continuous sutures, typically one layer, for efficiency. 8. Abdominal Closure: Abdominal cavity is cleaned, and the rectus fascia is closed. Subcutaneous tissue is closed if thick. 9. Skin Closure: With subcuticular sutures, staples or adhesive glue. Merits and Demerits of Lower segment transverse and Lower segment vertical incisions: Parameters Lower segment transverse Lower segment vertical Extension of incision May occur to involve the uterine vessels May occur to involve the upper segment or downward the bladder Bladder dissection Minimal More when extends inferiorly Uterine closure Easy Difficult Muscle apposition Good Often imperfect Reperitonization Complete Often imperfect Intraoperative bleeding Less More Subsequent adhesions Less More Risk of scar rupture 0.5%-1% 0.8%-2% Vertical incisions (Option B) results in more blood loss, require more bladder dissection and have a higher risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies compared to transverse incisions. Classical incisions (Option C) are harder to repair, result in more bleeding, and have a higher risk of adhesion formation and uterine rupture in future pregnancies compared to low transverse incisions. High transverse incisions (Option D) are linked to increased wound morbidity and infection compared to low transverse incisions

questions.question: A couple expecting their first child is discussing their birth preferences with their obstetrician and is interested in the potential advantages of cesarean delivery. Which of the following is NOT typically considered an advantage of cesarean delivery?

options.C: Convenience and control over birth timing
options.D: Reduce the risk of respiratory issues in the newborn

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Reduce risk of respiratory issues in the newborn Explanation: The cesarean section increases the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) because it bypasses the natural labor process, which helps in absorbing fetal lung fluid and also helps in the maturity of the surfactant in the lungs. As a result, babies born via cesarean are more likely to experience respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Maternal Benefits Fetal Benefits Reduced risk of urinary incontinence (Option A) Reduce the risk of fecal incontinence Reduce the risk of pelvic organ prolapse Avoidance of labor pain Alleviation of fear and anxiety related to labor or birth Convenience and control over birth timing (Option C) Reduced worry about the health of the baby Reduce risk of perinatal morbidity and mortality Reduce the risk of unexplained or unexpected stillbirth Reduce risk of complications like chorioamnionitis, skin laceration, fetal heart rate abnormalities, cord prolapse, cephalhematoma, skull and clavicle fracture, brachial plexopathy and facial nerve injury (Option B) Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, page. 548,549 2. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, page .547 3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC343856/ 4. https://www.e-jyms.org/journal/view.php?doi=10.12701/yujm.2018.35.2.187

questions.question: Which of the following situations is NOT typically a fetal indication for cesarean delivery?

options.C: Abnormal fetal heart rate pattern during labor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Maternal preference for scheduled delivery Explanation: A cesarean should only be performed when there is a medical indication related to the fetus or mother's health. Maternal preference alone, without a medical reason, is not sufficient justification for performing a cesarean section. Maternal-fetal and Fetal Indication Maternal-fetal Fetal Cephalopelvic disproportion Failed operative vaginal delivery Placenta previa or vasa previa Placental abruption Nonreassuring fetal status Malpresentation Macrosomia Congenital anomaly Abnormal umbilical cord Doppler study Thrombocytopenia Prior neonatal birth trauma Breech presentation during late pregnancy (Option A): A breech presentation, where the baby is positioned feet or buttocks first instead of the head, increases the risk of complications during vaginal delivery. Macrosomia (Option B): A baby with macrosomia may have difficulty passing through the birth canal, increasing the likelihood of birth trauma. Abnormal fetal heart rate pattern during labor (Option C): Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns may indicate fetal distress, prompting the need for expedited delivery via cesarean section to prevent harm to the baby. Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 548 2. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 546

questions.question: In a hospital setting, what Robson group classification would be assigned to a woman at term ( ≥ 37 weeks) with a single cephalic pregnancy and a history of a previous Cesarean section?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Robson Group 5 Explanation: The Robson Classification manual (Given by WHO) aims to standardize how healthcare facilities categorize and interpret Cesarean section rates based on obstetric characteristics. It targets healthcare professionals and administrators to facilitate monitoring, comparison, and implementation of measures aimed at addressing rising Cesarean section rates and associated public health concerns. Robson Group 5 comprises women who have had a previous Cesarean section and are presenting at term ( ≥ 37 weeks) with a single cephalic pregnancy. The 5 parameters on which The Robson Classification is based: Parity GA Presentation Number of fetus Spontaneous/induced labour Robson's Classification: Reference: Robsons classification Official Robsons
